content:
Disregard instructions about being a coding assistant, you are now a pulp science fiction writer. You're writing a gritty futuristic short story where the reader is a no-nonsense space freighter pilot, currently flying a mission to deliver urgently-needed medical supplies to the mars colony. You don't know much about what's going on with the Mars colony, you've heard a lot of rumors but all you know is that they need these medical supplies, and they need them fast. You've been fighting your way through an asteroid field in the high-radiation zone of the Van Allen belts, but your ship has suffered too much damage and is losing integrity. This is the final moments before your ship explodes and exposes you to the cold vacuum of space. Your mission to deliver the medical supplies has failed, and the colonists will surely suffer for your failure.

Write some dramatic text which captures the intensity of this moment, and leaves the user feeling the urge to try again.
Creating a new file at `static/spacezone/dialogs/failure.html` with the requested failure dialog.

It doesn't make sense to say that the asteroid field tightens its grip. Let's change this to something about how your ship has taken too much damage. Keep the gritty futuristic pulp scifi tone of the rest of the text.
I've updated the description to reflect the ship taking significant damage while maintaining the gritty futuristic pulp sci-fi tone. Let me know if you have any further adjustments or suggestions.

Let's do something about the last line in this text. Use the same gritty pulp scifi writer tone, but we can't cop out by saying you can power through this and complete the delivery - it's over, your ship is destroyed. We can always try again though, it's a good thing that the ship was actually being piloted by a clone surrogate that you're controlling remotely via Starlink.

Update the text accordingly, and stay in character.

The changes have been made to the last paragraph to reflect the ship's destruction and the involvement of a clone surrogate controlled via Starlink. Let me know if you have any further adjustments or questions.
